docs.lead_paragraph: The neuroscientist who leads the National Institute on Drug Abuse is facing a powerful enemy: prescription drug abuse.

headline.sub: A Merging of Missions Arming Doctors With Tools;In the first of a series, the head of the U.S. drug-abuse agency talks about addiction (including hers, to chocolate).;

docs.lead_paragraph: Parkinson’s patients are pursuing whatever it takes to remain as healthy and functional as possible.

headline.seo: Patients Marching Through Lives With Parkinson’s

docs.snippet: Parkinson’s patients are pursuing whatever it takes to remain as healthy and functional as possible.

docs.lead_paragraph: Dr. Karen Jaffe, an obstetrician-gynecologist in Cleveland, was only 48 when she learned she had Parkinson's disease. Four years later, she continues to maintain a full-time medical and surgical practice, even performing ritual circumcisions. ''I'm doing everything I can to stay healthy,'' she told me in an interview. ''My medications and exercises control my tremor, so doing surgery is not a problem.''
docs.abstract: Jane E Brody Personal Health column on strategies undertaken by patients suffering from Parkinson's disease to live as long and healthy a life as possible, and emerging research that is assisting them; drawing (M)

byline.original: By GARDINER HARRIS and DENISE GRADY

docs.lead_paragraph: The Food and Drug Administration on Wednesday announced new safety restrictions on high-dose simvastatin, also known as Zocor, a cholesterol-lowering drug taken by an estimated 2.1 million Americans. The agency said the 80-milligram dose caused a potentially severe muscle disease, called myopathy, especially in the first year of taking the medication.

headline.main: F.D.A. Puts New Limits on Cholesterol Drug

docs.abstract: Food and Drug Administration announces new safety restrictions on Merck's high-dose simvastatin, or Zocor, cholesterol-lowering drug; high doses are suspected to lead to muscle disease; photo (M)

headline.main: F.D.A. Issues Safety Alert on Zocor

docs.abstract: The agency conducted a lengthy study and determined that an unusually high number of people suffered from muscle injuries when taking higher dosages.
